My bottle was billed as 2016 Southern Charred, Double Bastard Aged in Whiskey Barrels. The label says it is 12.6% ABV. I didnt think the Templeton Rye Barrel Aged version of Double Bastard was particularly better than regulation Double Bastard. But this... this is really something noteworthy. This beer looks like Double Bastard on the pour, its dark caramel brown with little head. The aroma is just gorgeous. It smells like Double Bastard, but has huge, warm, buttery bourbon character. Vanilla, spice, rich and woody and strong. The flavor is bigger and bolder still. Its complex and rich and absolutely delicious. Nutty, toasted, sweet and strong, with burnt sugar and earthy, ochre notes. The finish is spacious and warm, and the big blast of the ABV hits the nose like a ghost train. This is a beer to save for special occasions, or to make any occasion special.

Aroma is musty old ale with whiffs of caramel, brown sugar, toffee, vanilla, smokiness from the bourbon barrel, and a slight tannic, acidic scent. The flavor is all of the above  on steroids  followed by a balancing hop bitterness and the boozy burn of its 12.6 percent-alcohol. Mouthfeel is syrupy with almost no carbonation. A good winter sipper. Typical of the Arrogant Bastard beers, not for the meek.

January 24th, 2014 - Folks in San Diego are going crazy for this expensive trio of beers, and the chili pepper permutation was a shock and a bust, to both the palate and the wallet. The Charred is a marked improvement, and while it is not an overly complex brew, it bears all the marks and heralds of Stone Brewing, and is almost as iconic as Arrogant Bastard itself. It pours like stirred up mud, the color of a dark, black tea, and a thin head colored with a touch of auburn. The aroma is surprisingly quiet, given all the boasting in the marketing and on the label, though when I do go in for a sniff I get slapped with an oak chip. But its a welcome slap, bringing out a deep, heady smoky wood smell, combined with that distinctive stone scent so often found in their amber beers (and everything darker on the color spectrum.) The most noticeable aspect of the flavor is a soft, velvet palate, with loosens up around the mid-taste, and ends with a foamy flourish. The flavors are mostly in the oak family, with a booziness swimming around at every stage. The oak touches balance deftly with the hops and malt bill in a compelling way, and better represents the arrogance of Stones style than their headline brew. As it warms, a deeper Maillard reaction richness develops in the flavor, as well as a more three dimensional hop profile. It doesnt get more complex than this, but it does stay bold and strong through the whole of the evolution. That, in conjunction with the iconic flavors, make this a good investment and a fine - and slow sipping - beer.

2013 bottling; Sampled February 2014
A steady pour into my New Belgium globe glass produces a one finger thick, amber tinged, tan colored head. The beer is a dark, concentrated amber color that shows a richly hazy, red-amber hue when held up to the light. The aroma smells tart, of vanilla, toasted coconut, with some rich buttery oak notes, and lots of warming, spicy, Bourbon fruit character and alcohol.

Slightly sweet, perhaps a touch of Bourbon tartness, and a finish that is quite oak influenced with a mix of rich, buttery, toasted coconut and vanillin character. Bitter hop notes have mellowed quite a bit, but are still quite present and help to balance the rich malt and sweet accentuating Bourbon notes; the bitterness gets a bit more firm in the finish where it combines with a bit of hot alcohol. Fruit notes of concentrated plum, and a touch of fig, as well as lots of fruit leaning Bourbon notes. Rich, definitely a sipping brew, though the barrel aging lightens the beer up just a bit.

Beers with a strong Bourbon barrel influence just arent my thing in the end; this is enjoyable in small amounts, and the Bourbon heat can get to be a bit too much after a bit.

DB with a softer though still aggressive hop bite and a big, whiskey barrel front and rear. Really fully on. One to groove on and savour.

Smooth edges, decadent flavor profile, damn near perfect.

500 ml caged and corked bottle (labeled as Southern Charred), bottled October 2013. A great beer that has a fantastic balance between the peppers and malts and oats.

Bottle, as Southern Charred. Pours cloudy hazel, medium creamy tan head, dissipates slowly with nice lacing. Quite a pretty beer. Aroma is bourbon, toffee, toasted caramel, vanilla, oak, other dark sugars. Flavor is fairly sweet and medium bitter, rich and malty, vanilla and bourbon everywhere. Full body, rich creamy mouthfeel. Bottled as Southern Charred
Pours a deep red color, almost flat... but not perfectly still 

The aroma is only lightly boozy but offered toffee & apple mostly, its bourbony & defiantly sweet smelling, but inviting and enjoyable all the same. 

The flavor is only lightly bitter with a tinge of that caramel malt on piney hop that I just dont like about the "Bastards", this element is actually so minor that it serves as a sort of pleasantry as opposed to a general annoyance that I find it to be in basically every other beer in this family. Its loaded with toffee flavor, vanilla, burnt sugar, brown sugar, & Bourbon. 

The palate is mouth coating and the extremely low carbonation seems to fit just fine here. 

It almost pains me to rate something from the "Bastard" line this high as I have very little regard for Arrogant Bastard or any of the takes on it, but this is something else completely... the beer that emerged from those barrels was transformed from the beer that went in... 
Ive got to fall on my sword and declare this one is delicious.

12.6% ABV Southern Charred, chosen to be on my second flight on 17th March 2014 while visiting the Stone outlet at Liberty Station, San Diego. Murky brown in appearance, it didnt look too great to be honest, the tanned head being thin and grubby. Luckily the aroma and taste nullify the looks, as the dark fruits and maltiness (coffee and toffee being the leads) make you forget what your eyes can see. Different and interesting, like so many I tried in the gardens on that sunny afternoon.

500 ml bottle labeled "Southern Charred" 2013 series batch 7, 12.6% ABV. No audible pop when cork pulled. Pours murky caramel color with no head. Bourbon and caramel aroma with some oak and vanilla. Similar flavors with bourbon dominating. Some toasted malts and dark fruits also. Medium to full body with no carbonation.

2013 series, batch #7, 500 bottle. Thanks again, Mark! Pours Amber Brown with very little head. Complex mix of aromas, Caramels, Vanilla, Honey, and Whiskey, all blended together. 2013 series, batch # 07 500 ml 12.6% ABV. Large tan head with good retention and plenty of lacing. Quingenti Millilitre bottle from binnys Lakeview. From the bottle: "Southern Charred", 2013 series (bottled 10/2013), batch 7, 2012 Double Bastard Ale (brewed 8/2/12 and 11/2/12) aged in bourbon barrels, 95 IBU, 12.6%. Arrogant Bastard Ales (really) big brother, this dark amber ale is brewed with a huge malt bill and a belligerent amount of hops. Its a heavy, bitter beast of a beer and absolutely not for the timid. 41% aged 13 months in second-use Kentucky bourbon barrels, 51% aged 10 months in Kentucky bourbon barrels, and 8% aged 10 months in charred American oak barrels. The charred American oak barrles lend intense smoke and vanilla flavors, while the Kentucky bourbon barrels add nuances of butterscotch and caramel. These meld with rich dark chocolate notes produced by Kentucky bourbon barrels that once held Stone Suitable For Cave Aging -- an imperial smoked porter tribute to Danny Williams to produce a very complex, well-structured beer with intense flavor." amazed that just 8% of the blend gives it such charred intensity. hops well-hidden.

Lots of burnt sugar is prevalent throughout... Well made beer.

Half liter bottle (batch #7) thanks to the cork-pooping AndyReynolds. Gracing this liquid by pouring it into a Trappist glass. Nose is dark fruit, brown sugar, and white wine. Sip adds booze and bourbon for sure. I get moonshine. Boozy indeed. Slight walnut skin aftertaste. More moonshine.

Shared with EricTeusink creeping out some kids in the park. Agreed with him that the charred version should completely be a different rate. Taste is really what set this one apart as a memorable experience. The bourbon was not over the top, the blending of the barrels was well thought out, the charr being on 8% was neither too strong nor too subtle. It was a big beer, boozy for sure, spicy from the charr and bourbon, vanilla, a bit on the heavy side, but I could certainly take the whole 500 ml with pure enjoyment. A really nice barrel treatment or treatments.

Southern Charred Variant. I think RateBeer was wrong to lump this variant in with Whiskey Aged Double. Totally unique beer. Pours a kinds of unappealing hazy light medium brown with small tan head. Either the barrel or the combination of the barrel and the age has kind of chopped this up. I like Double Bastard aged, but the barrel may take away from this just a bit.

2009 bottle thanks to deftim13 during RBWG 2013. Hazy mahogany pour with a small khaki head. Dark fruits, dates, caramel, a bit of BA, wood, and vanilla on the aroma. Light oxidation in the flavor, burnt caramel, dark fruits, and maltiness. Not bad.

Bottle. Poured light brown color with an average to large frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy malt, whiskey wood and earth hop aroma. Copious body with a smooth slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy whiskey bittersweet flavor to medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where met with a complex solid beer.

Sample from a 500ml bottle, shared by brew3crew. 2009 Vintage. Mostly clear brown color. Some particles floating about in the body. Pours with a nice bigger khaki head. Few bits of lace. Woody, lightly spicy aroma. Hint of dark fruit. Bigger body. Smooth, lighter kind of soft carbonation. Dry finish. Some alcohol warmth. Moderate bitterness. Very interesting stuff, not bad despite the heat

500 ml bottle to snifter (2009 BB vintage; muled for the group by brew3crew). Looks good; a cloudy amberish-brown with fluffy light beige head that dissipates into sticky lacing. Smells HOT and malty. Tastes like it smells, only smoother and more balanced. You get some hops in there too. Solid on the palate. Solid, but not spectacular.

This golden Byron beer has a lovely vanilla aroma. It has a strong bite but complex sweet flavors. The alcohol doesn't come through too strong for how high a % it is.

Dark red pour with a very bourbon heavy and toffee aroma.  Taste is bourbon toffee and vanilla.  Pretty good.

2009 bottle .. . aged and cork .. . deep brown .. mild mouth .. . age has slashed this beer up .. . . i was reading the dictionary, I thought it was a poem about everything.

24th January 2013 THE Others tasting. 2009 Bottle. Another much wanted beer landed by Bruce - cheers mate! Hazy deep amber - brown beer. Massive pale cream - tan head. Palate is light, crispy and semi dry. Bitterish dry wood and oxidised malt and mild cheese. Aniseed and alcohol spice. Finishes dry and bitter. Interesting but probably a bit past it.

Beautiful garnet color, but lacking in balance and palatability. The abv makes this beer tempting, but what we're really talking about here is barley wine; great if that's what you're looking for, but calling this an ale is almost a misnomer.

---This rating is likely a compilation of my and my roommates' musings over our latest beer pick up. We are all self-proclaimed beer connoisseurs. All ratings and comments are decided through deliberation, discussion, and (frequently) bloodshed. Let this not be in vain.

bottle. 2009 vintage thanks beau! pours murkey dirty red. white head. aroma is slight whiskey and malty bastard. taste has more barrel then nose leeds on to. finish is smooth loads of burnt sugar and caramel.

Bottle (Vintage 2009) at The Others Tasting, London - big thanks to Bruce for bringing this one. Pours hazy maroon with a fine, off-white foam head. Some dry caramel and toffee in the nose, dry fruits, dates. Medium to big sweet flavor with toasty brown bread, caramel and alcohol-soaked berries. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Moderately warming finish with light bitter earth, some torched wood, and toasty sugars. Tasty beer, pretty hefty.

Bottle @ THE Others Tasting. Thanks to Bruce for hunting this down! The pours deep red with a small off-white head. The aromas quite woody. Plenty of bourbon, some raisin, singed grass and cherry scones. The taste is sprucy hops, burnt wood and grass. Hot bourbon, caramel and vanilla. Sweet, malty profile. A touch of milk chocolate. Hints of spearmint on the finish. Full bodied, a sipper for sure. This drinks big, even for the out-sized ABV. Overall, a decent beer. Not completely dialed-in. Not a favorite, but interesting.

2009 bottle thanks to Bruce at THE others tasting. It pours hazy deep mahogany with a yellow-white head. The nose is wood, vanilla, toasted coconut, raisin, date, bourbon, varnish and spice. The taste is wood, varnish, bourbon, fruit cake, spice, earth, burnt note, nice bitterness and some alcohol warmth with a dry, bitter finish. Medium-full body, moderate carbonation and sticky-mouth-feel. Fairly alcoholic, but pretty tasty indeed.
bottle. bourbony vanilla notes, rich maltiness, caramel & toffee. BIG, rich & flavorful. Bourbon, toffee richness, not as boozy as expected at 11.5%, light wood aging. Delicious beer

Bottle... Pours brown with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. The aroma is a luxurious mélange of toasted oak, bourbon and toasted coconut.  Ultra full-bodied and velvety with tickling carbonation. The flavor is certainly bitter, but not nearly as rough around the edges as the base beer. It features heavy citrusy bitterness flanked by discreet notes of bourbon and toffee. Lengthy, bitter finish. Bottle courtesy of ctipping!
hazy dark amber color with ivory sheen. Big whiskey, booze, caramel, mild roast aromas. medium body. Vanilla flavors with sweet spicy caramel, toast, wood. Boozy warming finish--not bad.

Bottle shared tonight by Ron. 500ml. Pours a light clear brown with tiny head. Aroma is of an over the hill IPA. Malt forward, vanilla, sweetness. Taste is vanilla, toffee, faded hops and small barrel character. The barrel really doesnt come into play here other than a tiny amount of whiskey in the finish heat. Not a huge fan.

text: (Bottle)  Pours an amber-brown body with a medium off-white head.  Aroma of vanilla, caramel, bourbon, brown sugar, and wood.  Flavor of caramel, bourbon, grass, fruit, and herbs with a dry wood finish.

Pours a deep mahogany with a half finger of reddish brown off white head. Nose and taste are of whiskey, wood, and sweet malts. They really did everything right with this beer when it comes to balance. While it was not a game changer it was much appreciated, and very much enjoyed.

Pours a dark caramel with a scattered thin head. Huge bourbon nose with roasty caramel, some vanilla and a fruity note that are hard to place. Malt dominates the taste early with some bitterness creeping in before sweet bourbon takes over, leading to an increasingly boozy finish. Definitely a sipper. Its nice, but not nearly as smooth as I expected given the age (2009).

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy deep amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty woody bourbon and vanilla aroma with hints of caramel. Fruity malty bourbon caramel and vanilla flavor with weak hoppy bitter hints. Has a fruity malty bourbon caramel and vanilla finish.

Nice brown pour, tan head.  Aroma is full of big bourbon notes, vanilla, coconut, roasted nuts, prunes, raisins, alcohol.  Flavor is very malty, lots of bourbon, vanilla, some molasses and raisins.  Nice sipper!

500ml, corked & caged, classy looking bottle (2009) as an unbelievable extra from deftim13. thanks so much, Tim! pours a hazy, reddish copper topped by a thin, whispy, khaki head that leaves a razor thin ring of lace. aroma is absolutely wonderful with huge notes of sweet toffee, burnt caramel, and honey backed by rich vanilla and dark fruit notes of raisins, blackberries, grape tannins, and baked apples with heavy oak and smokey bourbon shining as it warms. flavor is spectacular as well with everything i love about aged double bastard - rich toffee, orange spice cake, caramel apples, raisins, figs, and pine resin beautifully complemented by sweet vanilla, toasted oak, hints of cocoa, and marvelously smooth, slightly spiced bourbon. palate is full bodied, rich, and bold - emobodying everything that is double bastard - with a long, lingering, semi-sweet, oak and toffee finish. overall, a simply awesome barrel aged offering from Stone.

Copper in color with a small off-white head.  Huge booze/bourbon aroma on this.  Lots of dark fruit, wood, vanilla, and sugar aromas as well.  But mostly booze.  Things are a touch more mellow on the palate, but still fairly heavy on the bourbon.  Lots of vanilla, dark fruit, nuts, and brown sugar and caramel.  Really an intense aroma and flavor to this, hopefully it mellows out a bit.

Tap at RNH.  Deep amber pour.  Aroma is laden with bourbon character.  Oaky vanilla and fairly vineous behind the soft sweet malt.  Toffeeish and a little bit of spiciness on the nose.  Rich with a nice silken palate and a little bit of lingering tannic barrel character.  The hops have faded in the aroma quite a bit, but they are still there - just less piny and more fruity/herbal.  Peppery and a little bit chewy.  Its loaded with oaky/bourbon character but its nice.

Draft.  Pours an a dark amber with a tan lacing.  Holy bourbon barrels batman, nice aroma, chewy almost a roasted malt chocolate bourbon feel.  Viscous and big bodied with a hint of vanilla and lush fruit.  A solid brew, i had me a second one.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2016 "now thats a big beer. double bastard has been growing on me already, and after a couple cask and barrel aged beers at Stones 2009 Winter Storm Ive come to the conclusion that they do the barrel thing really well. DB is good, this version is great (2006). Great taste, balance and complexity!"

NOT retired at Stone as of 1/09!!!

I do NOT think southern charred should be listed as the same beer as this as the barrels are vastly different.  if this is the same beer, then so are all the varieties of Eclipse (and Im not arguing that, Im just making a point)...but so be it.  SC is not quite as awesome as the old school whiskey barrels...more sweetness, 13.2%, not 11 or 12.  Body still ridiculously smooth, just not quite as complex.  On its own would be 4.5 (taste a 9 instead of 10, and overall an 18 instead of 19.

2006 Bourbon barrel aged at NOTB 2009. Poured a reddish brown with minimal head. Aroma of vanilla, oak barrel, toffee, caramel, and some grapefruit citrus hops still holding on despite the age. Medium bodied with lively bubbly carbonation despite being 3 years old and barrel aged. Flavor of vanilla bourbon, wood, burnt caramel/toffee, slight hop bitterness and a good dose alcohol. Nice but this one drank very hot from the bourbon aging.

Broubon barrel aged Double Bastard 06, at the 08 double bastard release.  Pours a deep reddish brown, with very thin head.  The bourbon is reserved, and almost muted.  Strong caramel malts, mollasses, oak, vanilla, earthiness, and some bitter hops still hanging in there.  The mouthfeel is soft and syrupy.  Very good, but the french oak barrel was better.

2004 Bourbon Barrel Aged Double Bastard Ale on-tap at Double Bastard Ale Night at the Stone Brewery. Pours an almost clear, reddish brown color. No head, only a few large bubbles. Smells of bourbon and oak. Tastes of bourbon and oak as well. Also tastes of sweet malts. A little hop spiciness buried under all of that as well. Totally flat, which is a bummer because this brew really does taste good. Brew is thick but it feels thin with the lack of carbonation. Great barrel-aged beer. I just wish it had carbonation.

On tap at Stones 2007 Double Bastard Night.  Listed as 2004 Bourbon Barrel.  No head, except for huge bubbles from pour.  Bourbon is present in araom, but not overpowering.  Nice bitter/sweetness balance, but leans sweet.  Very, very delicious.  Double Bastard is one of my favorite beers.  I have been collecting and aging these.  I now have 04,05,06, and 07.  Tasted with kp, eyedrinkale, oodeftone (on BA), and darkelf.

Wow, its been a while since anyone has rated this one. Not sure if its the same batch, but had it on tap at Stone brewery/bistro. 2004 Bourbon Barrel Double Bastard during Double Bastard night, Nov.29 2007. Hazy copper color with no head, quite flat but wreaking with bourbon whiskey notes, sticky malt, cinnamon and hops. 3 years of age have mellowed it out a lot, and the presence of oak is noticeable. Slightly syrupy mouthfeel, like brandy, with the hops still putting on the bitterness at each sip. Highly enjoyable.

Hell ya, i was at the strong ale fest 04, i sampled some of this fine beer during my journey of drunkeness. All i can say is big, this beer was huge, it had a body like a lineman and an attitude like... Just really huge, definite kick up from the double.

Sampled at Strong Ale Fest 2004. Didnt enter the rating sooner due to the fact I didnt think it would be considererd a seperate beer. To much goign on here. A beer that was already pretty extreme is pushed over the edge by the whiskey barrel aging. Over the top hops bludgeoned by harsh bourbon notes with oakiness that would be overbearing in any beer but this. Put this under MAYBe try again.
Strong Ale 04. One of my top 3 beers at the fest. This stuff was lightly oaked, silky smooth and oh so tasty. Rich honey taste and lightly hopped. Im hoping this will be the 05 3L, hint.

Tasted at the 2004 Pizza Port Strong Ale Fest. Whisky amber color. Small to no head, Aroma is brown sugar, caramel, whiskey and oak. A medium to full bodied American Strong Ale. Malts are caramel and brown sugar. Orange peel and citrus, some oak. Thick and oily mouthfeel. In other words in tastes like Double bastard that has had some oak aging. Interesting beer, but I think I like the non-aged stuff better. Although I wouldnt mind have a few bottles of this stuff to cellar for a while. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

This beer was sampled at the San Diego Strong Ale Festival 2004. This beer was the first one I ran to at the fest. It poured a reddish dark brown color with a very small pearlish white head and minor lacing. The aroma is oakey, malty, with some tangy orange, alcohol, and slight whiskey. The flavor has some heavy orange/citrus and hard alcohol with a heavy dose of caramel and malt in the finish. Strangely enough well balanced and smooth. Medium mouthfeel with some brown sugar toward mid-sip. It had some obvious wood qualities as it warmed and it definitely had some fairly active carbonation. This was a well rounded solid beer, but call me crazy..I enjoyed the regular aged Double Bastard more.

On tap @ the San Diego Strong Ale Fest. Poured a medium to a dark brownish color with a very small off white head. Flavors and tastes of sweet (almost brown sugary), citrus (oranges) and of course Whiskey. Woody. Whiskey stronger in the taste than the smell. I enjoyed this much more than the regular Double Bastard.

The nose was really nice consisting of smokey, honey, whiskey, and malt.  The pour was rich golden brown w/ hints of red and orange.  The head was minor and almost no lacing.  Big whiskey and woody flavors w/ hints of honey sweetness and citrus undertones.  Creamy, medium body and little effervescence on the back of the tongue.

This bohemoth pours with a deep amber body topped by a thin head with little lacing.  The flavor and aroma are slightly sweetand fruity (orange?) with a nice alcohol note and a nice oak note.  Full bodied, smooth and slightly warming.
